title: Ravens to introduce new coordinators at press conference next week
description: Ravens head coach Jesse Minter will introduce his new trio of coordinators during a press conference next week.
fullText:
A little over a month after firing John Harbaugh, the Ravens have hired their new coaching staff headed by Jesse Minter. Offensive coordinator Declan Doyle, defensive coordinator Anthony Weaver, and special teams coordinator Anthony Levine Sr. fill out the rest of the top positions.

Minter will formally introduce his coordinators at a a press conference next Wednesday, scheduled for 11:00 a.m. ET at the team facility in Owings Mills, Maryland. It will be streamed on a variety of platforms, including the Ravensâ€™ mobile app.

Head coach Jesse Minter will hold a press conference Wednesday with new coordinators Declan Doyle, Anthony Levine Sr. and Anthony Weaver.

Livestream will be available on our Facebook page, YouTube, app and website pic.twitter.com/j7s0NxtqdW

â€” Baltimore Ravens (@Ravens) February 12, 2026

The Ravens have also released statements from Minter on each of his coordinators in the last few weeks as those hires became official.

Here is his statement on Doyle:

We are thrilled to welcomeÂ DeclanÂ to the Ravens Flock. An architect of offense,Â DeclanÂ will build around our players through communication, collaboration, relationships and trust. His innovative mindset, collaborative spirit, team-first approach and extensive NFL experience make him an outstanding addition to the Ravens organization.

A highly-regardedÂ defensive mind,Â AnthonyÂ WeaverÂ has a proven track record of success and is the definition of what it means to be a Raven. He elevates players with his football IQ, tactical knowledge and natural teaching ability â€”Â all attributes that make him one of the gameâ€™s most respected coaches.

AnthonyÂ has been instrumentalÂ in creating the high standard that is expected of Baltimoreâ€™s special teams unit. The toughness, discipline, focus and energy he brought as a player will define his impact as a coach. He embodies what it means to be a Raven, and Iâ€™m excited to see him embrace this role with the same relentless hard work and dedication heâ€™s shown our organization for many years.

title: Titans announce Robert Saleh's first coaching staff
description: The Titans finalized their coaching staff under head coach Robert Saleh, the team announced Thursday.
fullText:
The Titans finalized their coaching staff under head coach Robert Saleh, the team announced Thursday.

In addition to Saleh, the coaching staff consists of 14 other new additions with eight others returning from last season.

Previously, the Titans announced their three coordinators â€” Brian Daboll (offensive coordinator), Gus Bradley (defensive coordinator), and John Fassel (special teams coordinator).

Fassel also has assistant head coach as part of his title.

Here's a look at the complete staff:

Gus Bradley: Defensive Coordinator

Brian Daboll: Offensive Coordinator

*John Fassel: Assistant Head Coach/Special Teams Coordinator

*Ben Bloom: Senior Defensive Assistant

Carmen Bricillo: Offensive Line

*Trevor Browder: Offensive Assistant

Dalton Hilliard: Defensive Backs/Nickels

*Randy Jordan: Running Backs/Bill Walsh Diversity Coaching Fellowship Coordinator

Cade Knox: Offensive Assistant/Game Management

Marquand Manuel: Defensive Backs/Safeties

*Tony Oden: Pass Game Coordinator/Cornerbacks

John Rudnicki: Offensive Assistant

Ahmed Saleh: Defensive Assistant

*Travis Smith: Senior Defensive Assistant/Pass Rush Specialist

*Rayna Stewart: Assistant Special Teams

Aaron Whitecotton: Defensive Line

Isaac Williams: Assistant Offensive Line

* indicates returning member of the coaching staff

title: First moves, salary cap hits, and important Bills offseason dates
description: First moves, salary cap hits, and important Bills offseason dates
fullText:
The Buffalo Bills quietly kicked off their player personnel and salary cap action this week, as several players' contract guarantees kicked in for the 2026 NFL season.

4 #Bills players receive contract guarantees today.

WR Khalil Shakir's $11.9M 2026 salary is guaranteed.

LB Terrel Bernard's $8.9M 2026 salary is guaranteed.

CB Christian Benford's $14.5M 2026 salary & $2.5M of 2027 salary is guaranteed.

RB James Cook's $9.4M 2026 salary isâ€¦

â€” Spotrac (@spotrac) February 9, 2026

The team also has until this upcoming Monday, the 16th, to make re-signing decisions on any of the players on their roster who have void years remaining on their current contracts, as far as whether to use those years in new contracts. Those players are: Matt Milano (11M), Joey Bosa (7.2M), Connor McGovern (4.8M), AJ Epenesa (2.9M), and DaQuan Jones (3.7M).

Due to cap hit and the need to free up money, the front office and coaching staff may also soon examine what to do or rework in the contracts like those of Curtis Samuel, Dawson Knox, Ty Johnson, Taron Johnson, and Tyler Bass.

In the meantime, per the NFL transaction wire, Buffalo also made their first signings of the offseason, inking QB Shane Buechele and WR Jalen Virgil on free agent contracts. As neither player was currently under contract to any other team, they were free to sign with any club before the March 11 league year begins.

With a new coaching staff and coordinators in all three phases, there may be some additional personnel changes on defense as well, with new DC Jim Leonard's 3-4 concepts, in particular. This is another area the team may look at.

With new Bills DC Jim Leonhard likely to implement some 3-4 principles, here's a look at the salary cap impact of moving top-paid defenders through cuts and trades should the new staff feel that is necessary.

Some contracts are more tradable than I would've thought. https://t.co/QnZzAzrssE pic.twitter.com/KmQh1QNoYZ

â€” Nick Veronica (@NickVeronica) February 9, 2026

Some other important dates coming up this offseason will include the February 17th-March 3rd window to use franchise tags, the February 23rd-March 2nd NFL Combine, the March 9th-11th beginning of the "legal tampering" window in free agency, the March 11th 4 PM beginning of free agency, and the April 23rd-25th NFL Draft.

GM and President of Football Operations Brandon Beane and company will get to work on improving and strengthening the roster, which may also include more focus on doing so via trade(s) and the Draft, as the free agent market is notably a shallower talent pool this year.

This article originally appeared on Bills Wire: NFL AFC Buffalo Bills Football Josh Allen Brandon Beane offseason

title: Detroit Lions All-Time Team: Best Offense Ever Assembled
description: What if the greatest players in Detroit Lions history lined up together in their prime? Stafford under center, Sanders in the backfield, Megatron outside and Sewell in the trenches â€” this is the ultimate all-time Lions offense, built across generations.
fullText:
Have you ever wondered what the greatest Detroit Lions team ever assembled would look like?

Imagine Matthew Stafford dropping back behind an elite offensive line, handing the ball off to Barry Sanders or Jahmyr Gibbs, and throwing to Calvin Johnson and Amon-Ra St. Brown. It is a blend of eras â€” championship grit from the 1950s, star power from the 1990s and record-breaking production from today.

This is Part I of a two-part series constructing the greatest Lions team of all time. We begin with the offense.

Despite never winning a playoff game in Detroit, Stafford stands as the greatest quarterback in franchise history.

Staffordâ€™s rÃ©sumÃ© extends beyond his Lions tenure. A Super Bowl champion and league MVP, he ranks eighth all-time in passing yards and seventh in passing touchdowns. His arm talent, toughness and late-game heroics defined an era of Lions football. While Jared Goff delivered playoff victories and a Super Bowl appearance, Staffordâ€™s career production and hardware ultimately give him the edge.

At his peak, Stafford was capable of carrying an offense. In an all-time lineup loaded with weapons, his skill set would flourish even more.

Running Backs: Barry Sanders and Jahmyr Gibbs

Rather than stacking the field with three wide receivers, this all-time offense leans into Detroitâ€™s historic strength â€” dynamic running backs.

Barry Sanders is a lock. Sanders ranks fourth all-time in rushing yards despite playing only nine seasons. He never rushed for fewer than 1,300 yards in a season and remains widely regarded as the greatest running back in NFL history. His vision, balance and elusiveness are unmatched.

Pairing Sanders with Jahmyr Gibbs creates a nightmare for defenses. Gibbs, still early in his career, has already established himself as one of the leagueâ€™s most explosive offensive players. He broke Sandersâ€™ franchise record for most touchdowns before turning 24, reaching 48 total touchdowns. Though he has yet to earn First-Team All-Pro honors, his trajectory suggests it is only a matter of time.

Together, Sanders and Gibbs would form one of the most electrifying backfields imaginable.

Wide Receivers: Calvin Johnson and Amon-Ra St. Brown

Few franchises can match the star power of this duo.

Calvin Johnson, known simply as â€œMegatron,â€ was a true unicorn. He recorded 329 receiving yards in a single game, the second-most in NFL history, and set the single-season receiving yardage record with 1,964 yards in 2012, surpassing Jerry Rice. Johnson led the league in receiving yards twice and earned three First-Team All-Pro selections. His size, speed and red-zone dominance made him nearly unguardable.

On the opposite side is Amon-Ra St. Brown, who has been one of the most productive receivers in football over the past three seasons, including playoffs:

â€¢ 4,590 receiving yards (second in the NFL)

â€¢ 34 receiving touchdowns (first)

St. Brown has earned two First-Team All-Pro honors and one Second-Team selection, cementing himself among the leagueâ€™s elite. His route running, toughness and reliability would complement Johnsonâ€™s vertical dominance perfectly.

Charlie Sanders remains the gold standard at tight end in franchise history.

From 1968 to 1977, Sanders earned seven Pro Bowl selections and three First-Team All-Pro honors. A Pro Football Hall of Famer, he totaled 336 receptions for 4,817 yards and 31 touchdowns. In an era not known for pass-heavy offenses, Sanders was one of the first truly dynamic receiving tight ends.

His presence would add versatility and balance to this all-time offense.

Offensive Line: Lou Creekmur, John Gordy, Frank Ragnow, Larry Glover, Penei Sewell

Championship offenses begin in the trenches, and this group blends historic greatness with modern dominance. Combined, these five linemen account for 16 All-Pro selections and 22 Pro Bowl appearances.

Lou Creekmur anchors the unit. A six-time First-Team All-Pro and eight-time Pro Bowler, he was a cornerstone of Detroitâ€™s 1950s championship teams and is widely considered the greatest offensive lineman in franchise history.

John Gordy, a four-time First-Team All-Pro and six-time Pro Bowler, was a dominant guard during the Lionsâ€™ last championship era. His consistency and accolades cement his legacy.

Frank Ragnow brings modern excellence to the center position. A four-time Pro Bowler and three-time Second-Team All-Pro, he has been one of the leagueâ€™s top centers during the Dan Campbell era.

Larry Glover, a three-time Pro Bowler, provides steady veteran presence from the late 1970s and early 1980s.

Then there is Penei Sewell. A four-time Pro Bowler and three-time First-Team All-Pro from 2023 to 2025, Sewell has emerged as one of the NFLâ€™s premier tackles. Still early in his career, he is already on a Hall of Fame trajectory.

This all-time Lions offense blends eras, styles and philosophies. It has explosiveness in the backfield, dominance on the outside and power in the trenches.

In Part II, we will assemble the defense â€” and see if it can match the firepower of this historic offense.

title: Sam Darnold had the most heartwarming message for Jets fans
description: Super Bowl 60-winning quarterback Sam Darnold had the most heartwarming message for New York Jets fans.
fullText:
New York Jets fans have come to terms with the fact that Sam Darnold was better off elsewhere. The former No. 3 overall selection has done a fantastic job reviving his career since leaving the Jets. All of Darnold's hard work culminated in winning Super Bowl LX with the Seattle Seahawks this past weekend.

Darnold has kept it classy at every turn when discussing his tumultuous tenure with the Jets during Super Bowl media week. The Seahawks held their Super Bowl 60-winning parade in downtown Seattle on Wednesday. As per usual, Darnold was faced with occasional questions about the Jets in the wake of winning his first Lombardi Trophy.

One particular question and clip has rightfully gone viral. Justin Fried of The Jet Press asked Darnold if he had a message to Jets fans who have continued to support him despite things not working out between player and franchise. Darnold provided the most heartwarming response imaginable.

"Thank you," Darnold started with. â€œI always look at myself and feel like I couldâ€™ve done a lot more for that franchise. The fact that [Jets fans] are able to support me even through that means a lot.â€

Congratulations to Darnold on winning Super Bowl LX!

I asked Sam Darnold if he had a message to #Jets fans who have continued to support him:

â€œThank you.â€

â€œI always look at myself and feel like I couldâ€™ve done a lot more for that franchise.â€

â€œThe fact that [Jets fans] are able to support me even through that means a lot.â€ pic.twitter.com/AtOsbghHJN

â€” Justin Fried (@JustinTFried) February 10, 2026

This article originally appeared on Jets Wire: Sam Darnold had the most heartwarming message for Jets fans

title: After Back-to-Back Gold, Why Is Chloe Kim So Happy With Silver?
description: The second-place finish in this year's women's halfpipe finals may wind up meaning more to Kim than her past golds.
fullText:
Chloe Kim celebrates her second place in the women's halfpipe snowboarding final with the American flag at the Milano Cortina 2026 Winter Olympics in Livigno, Italy, on February 12, 2026. Credit - Oliver Weikenâ€”picture alliance/Getty Images

Youâ€™d be forgiven for disbelieving the smile on Chloe Kimâ€™s face Thursday night in Livigno, Italy, after she finished with a silver medal in the womenâ€™s Olympic halfpipe snowboarding finals. Kimâ€™s victories at the Olympics are typically inevitable. And after she finished first in qualifying earlier in the week, it seemed she had shaken the effects of the dislocated left shoulder she suffered back in early January. Winners refuse to accept second place, right?

But upon further review, Kimâ€™s jubilant reception of the silver medal at the Milano Cortina Games made all kinds of sense. In fact, this hardware may wind up meaning more to her than the golds she took home from PyeongChang in 2018 and Beijing four years ago.

â€œAbsolutely,â€ says Kim. â€œI mean, a month ago, I wasnâ€™t even sure if I would be here. I could get emotional thinking about it. I really worked hard to get here. So this metal means so much.â€

Following the competition, she walked down a snowy hill at the Livigno Snow Park halfpipe venue, hand-in-hand with her boyfriend, Myles Garrett of the Cleveland Browns, the NFLâ€™s reigning defensive player of the year, who stood with Kimâ€™s family and friends at the bottom of the halfpipe, snapping photos of Kim in action. â€œExciting but terrifying,â€ Garrett said, about watching Kim contort her body in the air on a snowboard.

Sheâ€™s got reason to be happy, personally and professionally. The new Olympic gold medalist, Goan Choi of South Korea, is now the youngest Olympic snowboard gold medalist, at 17 years, 101 days. Kim, who was also 17 when she won Olympic gold in PyeongChang, has become a mentor for Choi. If Kim walks away from snowboardingâ€”â€œIâ€™m aware that I canâ€™t do this forever,â€ she saysâ€”sheâ€™d leave the sport in good hands.

â€œShe's my baby. I've known her since she was so little, and I'm so proud of her,â€ says Kim. â€œIt means so much to me to know that I've inspired a whole new generation.â€

The night began in typical Chloe Kim fashion. Seven of the 12 finalists fell in their first run in snowy conditions, which made landing tricks more of a challenge. But Kim made no such mistakes, and her run was visibly superior, even through the snowfall. Her score, at 88.00, led the competition.

Each Olympic halfpipe finalist gets three runs, with the highest score the only one that counts. Could anyone surpass Kim in the final two runs? It had never happened before in the Games.

Kim had even held back in her first run. â€œI'll admit, I went pretty safe on it,â€ she says. â€œDidn't go as big as I was in practice, mainly because I was watching all these girls take slams, and I was like, let's just get to the bottom.â€

Entering her second run, Kim still held the lead. She tried to stretch her limits. â€œI wanted to try something I'd never done before,â€ says Kim. â€œI wanted to make history.â€ She fell.

Choi had a scary-looking accident in her first run; she remained in the middle of the halfpipe for a few minutes while receiving medical attention, but was able to ride to the bottom of her own accord. Choi thought about dropping out of the event.

Instead, she stunned the Livigno Snow Park by scoring a 90.25 on her final run, upping the eveningâ€™s ante. For the first time at the Olympics, Kim trailed. So sheâ€™d have to come through in the eveningâ€™s final attempt. â€œMy coach said, you know, you could do your first run better, or you can go for it,â€ says Kim. â€œI wanted to go for it. Because that's what I do.â€

She fell again, allowing Choi to claim the gold. â€œThe snow really started to come down, the wall started to get a little sticky,â€ says Kim. â€œNo excuses here. I should have made that mental note when I dropped in and felt it on my first hit. Yeah, I couldn't come through. But all good.â€

Kim made a beeline for Choi to congratulate her. â€œShe took a heavy slam, got back up and won the damn thing,â€ says Kim. â€œThat is badass.â€ Choi is not only the youngest Olympic snowboarding champion: sheâ€™s also the youngest X-Games halfpipe titleist ever, winning the event in 2023 and unseating Kim for that distinction as well.

Kim fell short in her bid to be the first snowboarder to win three straight Olympic golds. â€œI don't know if there really was a weight on my shoulders,â€ she says. â€œI feel like every time I go into a competition, it's always like, â€˜Oh, she can make history here. She could do this. She could do that.â€™ I'm just here to snowboard and whatever medal I get in doing so, great.â€

On Kimâ€™s itinerary upon her U.S. reentry: shoulder surgery. â€œIâ€™m excited for it to not be popping out all the time,â€ she says. Kim believes the injury cost her the key pre-Games training time needed to execute a flawless plan.

Not that sheâ€™s at all bummed about it.Â  â€œIn my eyes, Iâ€™m a winner,â€ says Kim. â€œBecause I was able to persevere and fight through.â€

Write to Sean Gregory at sean.gregory@time.com.

title: This iconic golf backdrop plays essential Winter Olympics role
description: Several miles off the coast of Turnberry, Scotland, sits a barren island whose precious granite plays a key role in the Winter Olympics.
fullText:
The original golf course at Trump Turnberry, on Scotlandâ€™s southwest coast, has some years on it: 125 to be exact. But thatâ€™s nothing compared to the age of one of the courseâ€™s famous neighbors: the uninhabited volcanic plug that stands sentinel in the Firth of Clyde about 10 miles off Turnberryâ€™s shoreline.

The origins of that wind-battered granite dome, which rises more than 11 stories out of the sea and is visible from nearly every hole on Turnberryâ€™s Aisla course, have been traced back 600 million years, to those lonely days when the continents were barren and the only signs of life came in the form of bacteria and eukaryotes.

Anyone whoâ€™s played at Turnberry â€”Â or, for that matter, Royal Troon or Prestwick, about 25 miles up the coast â€”Â will be familiar with the island for the magnificent backdrop it provides. Same goes for golf-watchers whoâ€™ve tuned into any of the four Open Championships that have been conducted on the Aisla course since 1977, most recently in 2009 when Tom Watson nearly claimed the Claret Jug at 59 years young.

The Aisla Craig featured prominently in all of those broadcasts, just as Torrey Pinesâ€™ hang-gliders or Pebble Beachâ€™s harbor seals do when the PGA Tour visits those storied venues. The rock is a staple of the Turnberry experience: an eroded magmatic pluton that not only inspires awe but also just so happens to play an essential role every four years in the Winter Olympic Games.

***

Ricky English isnâ€™t much of a golfer. â€œIâ€™ve tried it before, itâ€™s quite hard,â€ he told me earlier this week in a Scottish accent thicker than a pint of Belhaven Black. â€œItâ€™s one of those games where one hole you can play like Seve Ballesteros, and then the next hole itâ€™s in the woods and youâ€™ve lost your ball.â€

Besides, English spends most of his days thinking about another sport: curling. If youâ€™re even just a casual Olympics viewer â€” perhaps youâ€™ve been following the action in Milan over the past week â€”Â youâ€™re surely familiar with the pursuit, which has been awarding Olympic medals since the 1998 Games in Nagano, Japan. Curling, in the most basic terms, involves a â€œthrowerâ€ pushing a roughly 40-pound stone down a 150-foot-long sheet of ice, with the aim of stopping the stone as close as possible to the center of a target (aka â€œthe houseâ€) on the far end of the ice. Aiding in the process are two of the throwerâ€™s teammates who flank the stone as it slides down the ice, using â€œbroomsâ€, as needed, to reduce the iceâ€™s friction.

English knows a thing or two about those stones because he oversees the process of making them, as the operations manager of Kays Scotland, which since 2006 has been the exclusive manufacturer of curling stones for the Olympics. â€œWeâ€™re kind of servicing the whole sport,â€ English said of his small but mighty factory about a 45-minute drive north of Turnberry. â€œThereâ€™s only about 50 workers in here. Weâ€™re really busy.â€

It likely will come as no surprise from where Kays harvests its materials for the stones: yes, Aisla Craig her good self.

The islandâ€™s Blue Hone granite is used on the stoneâ€™s running edge while its Common Green granite, which is resistant to heat transfer and splintering, composes the body of the stone. Itâ€™s a formula Kays has spent the last 175 or so years perfecting, with granite that can be found nowhere else on earth. The factory, which is open four days a week, manufacturers about 12 stones a day or 48 per week with a sticker price of approximately $1,000/per (shipping not included). That might sound steep, but when you consider most stones last about 30 years, the cost also might sound like a bargain.

â€œWe have to keep our own quality standards up for every stone,â€ English said. â€œWhether we make a stone for the Olympics or we make a stone for a [curling] club in Alabama, itâ€™s the same quality control, the exact same way of making it goes into it. Thereâ€™s no difference.â€

Kays ships stones all over the world, from the U.S. to China, Japan and South Korea to Mongolia and New Zealand, even to . . . Antarctica. â€œTheyâ€™re using it as a kind of luxury experience type thing,â€ English said. â€œItâ€™s like minus-36 degrees, so I wasnâ€™t sure with the temperature and the conditions how the stones would be, but they seemed to be fine.â€

While the Aisla Craigâ€™s granite is uniquely suited for curling stones, it also has found its way into Turnberryâ€™s golf shop in the form of ball markers and other granite-based memorabilia. Kays also commissioned a St. Andrews clubmaker to build four hickory golf clubs into which Kays incorporated Common Green granite into the bases. They sold quickly. â€œSo, yes,â€ English said of his teamâ€™s handiwork, â€œthereâ€™s wee ties to golf.â€

English said he also sees some crossover between the skills required in both curling and golf, and, indeed, itâ€™s not hard to see the parallels between sliding a stone down a slab of ice and rolling a ball across a slick green. â€œThere are a few curlers that we know of that are actually really good golfers,â€ he said. â€œTheyâ€™ve got the type of skills from curling, with the touch and feel, and they kind of took that into golf.â€

But English has little time to work on his own swing or stroke. He has emails to answer and orders to fill, especially in this busy window during which his stones are enjoying their every-four-years moment in the international spotlight. To capitalize on the publicity, Kaysâ€™ online shop has been selling Olympics-themed giftware (coasters, drink cubes) made from Aisla Craig granite. The majority of orders thus far have come from the U.S., and English suspects thatâ€™s at least partly due to a certain rap legend on NBCâ€™s coverage team in Milan.

â€œSnoop Dog was at the curling,â€ English said. â€œThat might have helped.â€

Six-hundred million years of history doesnâ€™t hurt, either.

The post This iconic golf backdrop plays essential Winter Olympics role appeared first on Golf.

title: MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred optimistic major leaguers will play in 2028 Los Angeles Olympics
description: Manfred said there are still issues to resolve with the Major League Baseball Players Association before those Olympic aspirations are a reality.
fullText:
PALM BEACH, Fla. â€” Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred is optimistic that major leaguers will play in the 2028 Los Angeles Olympics.

Manfred, speaking following an owners meeting Thursday, said there are still issues to resolve with the Major League Baseball Players Association before those Olympic aspirations are a reality, but â€œI think weâ€™re a lot closer to there than we were the last time we talked about it,â€ he said.

The six-nation baseball tournament will be played from July 13-19 at Dodger Stadium. MLB is planning for an extended All-Star break between July 9 and July 21, with the All-Star Game likely at San Francisco on July 11.

An agreement with the union is needed.

â€œI sense a lot of momentum towards playing in LA in 2028,â€ Manfred said. â€œI think we are going to get over those issues. I think people have come to appreciate that the Olympics on U.S. soil is a unique marketing opportunity for the game. I think we had a lot of players interested in doing it and, you know, I feel pretty good about the idea (that) weâ€™ll get there.â€

In addition, an agreement is needed on insurance to cover player contracts for time with Olympic teams.

The United States will have an automatic berth in the both the baseball and softball tournaments and the top two other nations from the Americas in next monthâ€™s World Baseball Classic will earn berths.

MLB did not allow players on 40-man rosters to participate in the 2021 Tokyo Olympics, when Nippon Professional Baseball interrupted its season and Japan beat the U.S. 2-0 in the gold medal game.

Manfred was also asked if the involvement of Casey Wasserman, the prominent businessman and talent agent who has recently lost clients because of his appearance in recently released government files on Jeffrey Epstein, would deter the league from participating in the Olympics. He declined to comment on Wasserman, who is the chairman of the Los Angeles games, saying, â€œLook, our dealings are not with Casey. Our dealings are with the institution of the Olympics.â€

The addition of star outfielder Kyle Tucker by the Los Angeles Dodgers to what already was among the highest payrolls again sparked debate over whether management will propose a salary cap in collective bargaining this year.

Manfred said there hasnâ€™t been much movement in salary cap talks.

Tucker, the right fielder who is considered one of the best players in baseball, is the latest accomplished veteran brought in by the Dodgers, who have three of the top eight current contracts by average annual value. Los Angeles also signed top closer Edwin DÃ­az to bolster its bullpen.

â€œLook, I think great teams are always good for baseball,â€ he said. â€œI think with respect to this particular great team, it added to what we have been hearing from fans in a lot of markets for a long time about the competitiveness of the game. But great teams are always good baseball.â€

Bargaining is likely to start this spring on a labor contract to succeed the deal that expires Dec. 1.

â€œWeâ€™re in the preparation process,â€ Manfred said. â€œWe havenâ€™t agreed on a calendar with the MLBPA and it does take two to tango, as they say, but historically after opening day we kind of get started.â€

Manfred said there likely isnâ€™t a way around insurance issues that have come up for MLB-contracted players planning to play in next monthâ€™s World Baseball Classic. Several stars, including Puerto Ricoâ€™s Francisco Lindor and Carlos Correa, were left off their countriesâ€™ rosters because the WBC insurer wouldnâ€™t cover them.

â€œWe like that, when they say they want to play, obviously,â€ Manfred said. â€œBut then to have a problem with the insurance and the guy being unable to play, we recognize that. Iâ€™m just not sure that there is a way around it.â€

The tournament is co-owned by Major League Baseball and the Major League Baseball Players Association. Insurance is provided by National Financial Partners.

â€œIn order to get clubs comfortable with the idea that guys should play earlier in games they otherwise would not play, we had to protect them financially,â€ Manfred said.

Owners approved a rules change requiring first- and third-base coaches to remain in the marked coaching boxes. Coaches have frequently moved toward home plate, in a better position to better relay signs from the defensive team that may pick up.

MLB will produce and distribute local television broadcasts of at least 14 teams this season following financial problems of Main Street Sports Groupâ€™s FanDuel Sports Network.

â€œThe RSN situation has an impact on our revenue growth because the decline there is a drag on what is otherwise a growing industry,â€ Manfred said. â€œIt is true that the smaller markets have been hit harder than the larger markets, which impacts revenue sharing. Having said both of those, I think longer term, our content is inherently valuable. We deliver tons of eyeballs, and I think when we have an opportunity to get to market in 2028, weâ€™re going to be just fine.â€

Manfred said the 14 teams are â€œprobably making a little less than they made under their old contracts.â€

â€œThe key word there is old,â€ he added. â€œThe reason those contracts arenâ€™t there anymore was they were not economic given the cord-cutting thatâ€™s going on.â€

Teams approved two changes in controlling owners: Cincinnati Reds CEO Phil Castellini succeeds his father Minnesota Twins board member Tom Pohlad takes over from takes over from his younger brother Bob.

Manfred said of the San Diego Padresâ€™ sale process: â€œThere is robust interest in what is viewed as a really appealing asset.â€

Milwaukee chairman Mark Attanasio and Baltimore control owner David Rubenstein were voted to the eight-man executive council, replacing Arizona managing general partner Ken Kendrick and Seattle chairman John Stanton. The council also includes San Francisco chairman Greg Johnson and Cleveland chairman Paul Dolan (whose terms expire in 2027) and Miami chairman Bruce Sherman and Los Angeles Angels owner Arte Moreno (2028) and New York Mets chairman Steve Cohen and Athletics managing partner John Fisher (2029).

MLB approved extensions of its contract with Anheuser-Busch Cos. Inc. and of the deals for Comcast Corp. and Cox Communications Inc. to carry the Extra Innings package of out-of-market TV broadcasts.

title: US alpine skier Jacqueline Wiles survives plane crash to win Olympic bronze
description: The American womenâ€™s ski team have provided some extremely compelling stories at the 2026 Olympic Winter Games in Milan/Cortina dâ€™Ampezzo. From the serious injury to Lindsey Vonn to the unexpected gold medal by Breezy Johnson, you might not have heardâ€¦
fullText:
The American womenâ€™s ski team have provided some extremely compelling stories at the 2026 Olympic Winter Games in Milan/Cortina dâ€™Ampezzo. From the serious injury to Lindsey Vonn to the unexpected gold medal by Breezy Johnson, you might not have heard of the remarkable story of American alpine skier Jacqueline Wiles of Portland, Oregon.

According to Travis Pittman of the Central Oregon Daily, Wiles survived a plane crash seven months ago in Sisters, Oregon. At the time, Wiles was a passenger on a training flight when the plane dovetailed.

Wiles credits her boyfriend Maxime Boutemy of saving her life. Maxime helped Wiles out of the wreckage before the plane went into flames. Wilesâ€™s symptoms were a concussion and burns.

Before the accident occurred, Wiles had dreams of being a pilot. It will be interesting to see if those dreams still exist, or if Wiles will concentrate now fully on skiing.

Heading into the 2026 Olympic Winter Games, Wiles had won four World Cup downhill medals in alpine skiing, with a lot of success on the Olympic course. She had won a bronze medal at Cortina in 2018, and silver medal in Cortina in 2024.

Wilesâ€™s other two World Cup medals were bronze medals in Zauchensee, Austria. The first came in 2017, and the second came last month.

Wiles won her Olympic bronze medal with Paula Moltzan of Minneapolis, Minnesota on Tuesday. They had a time of 2:21.91, and beat Mikaela Shiffrin and Johnson by six one hundredths of a second to reach the podium in the womenâ€™s team combined competition. Austria won gold and Germany won silver.

title: USA 'never got deflated,' overcomes disallowed goals to down Latvia
description: The U.S. men's hockey team had two goals disallowed in the first period but there was "never any panic" as the Americans beat Latvia.
fullText:
MILAN - Brady Tkachuk tried to put into words what he had just experienced.

The Americans had just come off the ice at Milano Santagiulia Hockey Arena, where festive and loud fans ensured a fabulous atmosphere for the match against Latvia. Brady Tkachuk had the first goal, set up by his brother, Matthew, en route to a 5-1 victory over Latvia on Thursday, Feb. 12 in the preliminary round of the 2026 Winter Olympics men's hockey tournament.

"It was amazing, and it was great to see the flags, the chants,Â and just the support that you have here," Brady Tkachuk said. "Just a little example of the support you have back at home.Â You're playing in front of millions of Americans,Â and you just want to represent them well,Â and it's always an honor to put this jersey on."

More: U.S. men's hockey team ready to play after soaking up Olympic life

The ice received so-so reviews.

"I honestly didn't think it was that bad," defenseman Charlie McAvoy said. "I mean, you certainly notice it when it gets later in the period.Â I had a pretty solid toe pick in the third up top where I had to test my balance pretty good.Â There are some times where you're like digging in, getting stuck a little.Â But both teams have to play on the same ice, so you make do."

One of biggest pluses to come out of the game for the Americans may have been the second goal they had overturned. That was a lesson in the zero tolerance policy of international hockey when it comes to making contact with a goaltender in the crease.

"I don't know that I agreed with the call, but it doesn't matter what I think," coach Mike Sullivan said.

The Latvians also successfully challenged Brock Nelson was offside when Quinn Hughes put the puck in the net shortly after Tkachuk's goal. Latvia tied the game after the overturned goal. It could have been a tough stretch, but the Americans didn't falter.

"The energy on the bench is terrific," Sullivan said. "They never got deflated. They just, the self-talk and the talk amongst themselvesÂ about just staying with it and keep playing, that, we're going to be fine.Â And, of course, we were.Â But those types of moments, they can be game-changing moments."

Latvia never really posed a threat, even after making it 1-1. In the second period, shots favored the Americans, 17-2.

"I thought it was a hell of a first, but a couple of goals called back, and then it's just 1-1, but there's never any panic," Matthew Tkachuk said. "The second period on, we just wanted to make sure somebody was out of the net at all times. They were playing pretty tight.Â The skill and possession and strength that we have, we knew we were going to win some battles,Â but somebody had to be at the net, so we tried to make it harder on the goalie. We tried to make him haul us down."

Brock Nelson scored twice in the second period, nestled around a goal by Tage Thompson. Nelson's second goal was off tic-tac-toe passing from Jack Hughes.

Everything coming up BROCK. NELSON. #WinterOlympics pic.twitter.com/yy7xGkXiR0

â€” NBC Olympics & Paralympics (@NBCOlympics) February 12, 2026

"I was skating up the ice with Jack, a little bit of 2-on-1," Nelson said. "I just tried to give him a little bit more time and try to drive the back post. I peeled out, saw him make a drop pass and another guy come in and I thought maybe one of those guys was going to rip a one-timer, so I just kind of looped around. And then a couple great passes and poise by those guys. I find myself on the back side with space and an open net."

After Auston Matthews scored in the third period, the Americans eased off a bit. It was, all in all, an excellent first outing for them.

"I mean, just an unbelievable experience," Nelson said. "I tried to soak it all in. I thought our line was good and made a lot of great plays, good chances, good support and a good team win overall to get it going."

This article originally appeared on Detroit Free Press: USA adjusts after disallowed goals to beat Latvia: 'Never any panic'

title: Las Vegas Raiders All-Pro Weighing Decision to Request Trade
description: Things are looking up if youâ€™re a fan of the Las Vegas Raiders. New head coach Klint Kubiak is coming [â€¦]
fullText:
Things are looking up if youâ€™re a fan of the Las Vegas Raiders. New head coach Klint Kubiak is coming off a Super Bowl win as an offensive coordinator/playcaller. Now heâ€™ll take over the Raiders, where heâ€™ll still be calling plays. But now everyone wants to know if the Maxx Crosby trade rumors are legitimate.

According to NFL Networkâ€™s Tom Pelissero, the meeting Kubiak had with Crosby was a â€œpositiveâ€ one. However, that doesnâ€™t mean things are peachy in Vegas between the Raiders and their second-team All-Pro pass-rusher. Crosby is now weighing a decision of whether he wants to request a trade, but the Raiders still have a chance to salvage this.

â€œMy understanding is that conversation with Klint Kubiak was positive. But there are a lot of other fences that would need to be mended for Crosby to stay in Las Vegas. It is not an impossibility that Crosby is back with the Raiders. It is certainly a possibility that he is not. There are multiple voices here, including Maxx and Klint Kubiak, all the way up to Mark Davis, who are going to be a part of this decision.â€

NFL Networkâ€™s Tom Pelissero on Maxx Crosby

We canâ€™t blame Crosby, whoâ€™s easily one of the NFLâ€™s best defenders, for wanting to be a part of a winner. Heâ€™s played in one postseason game since he arrived as a fourth-round pick in the 2019 NFL Draft, yet heâ€™s made five Pro Bowl teams in that span.

In other words, Crosby is far from the reason why the Raiders have been so bad. Now he may want to be part of why a team is so good, and possibly even compete for a Super Bowl ring.

Thereâ€™s no telling how long that may take with the new-look Raiders, but Crosby may feel like heâ€™s been waiting this one out long enough. If so, several teams will be in a rush to present their best blockbuster trade offer for the sack master.

title: Daytona 500 pole sitter Kyle Busch racing against the odds in his 21st attempt in the race
description: Winning the pole position for a race is normally a good sign of how a driver will perform during the race, but the Daytona 500 has offered cruel results for drivers starting up front in the last two decades.  Eight of the 36 NASCAR Cup Series races were won from the pole in 2025, which is far away the most in the Next Gen era (since 2022).  Meanwhile, the Daytona 500 has had no pole-sitters win in the last 25 races.
fullText:
Winning the pole position for a race is normally a good sign of how a driver will perform during the race, but the Daytona 500 has offered cruel results for drivers starting up front in the last two decades.

Eight of the 36 NASCAR Cup Series races were won from the pole in 2025, which is far away the most in the Next Gen era (since 2022).

Meanwhile, the Daytona 500 has had no pole-sitters win in the last 25 races. Dale Jarrett was the last driver to win from the pole in 2000.

Kyle Busch will look to end the long-standing streak on Sunday in the 68th running of the Great American Race. Busch qualified on pole on Wednesday with a speed of 183.651. The streak wasn't on Busch's mind following the run, though.

"Being able to qualify on my first pole for the Daytona 500, thatâ€™s pretty special,â€ Busch told NASCAR.com on Wednesday. â€œThis feels good. Feels really good for RCR as a group."

Busch will make his 21st start in the Daytona 500 on Sunday. Despite winning two NASCAR Cup Series titles, 63 race victories, and countless other accolades, it's been 20 years of trying and 20 years of frustration for Busch in the sport's biggest race.

Chase Briscoe's 4th-place run in 2025 is the best finish for a Daytona 500 pole winner during the streak. Briscoe will start alongside Busch on the front row in Sunday's race.

Drivers have won the Daytona 500 from the pole nine times, including Richard Petty (1966), Bill Elliott (1985, 1987), and Jeff Gordon (1999).

Busch says his lack of a Daytona 500 victory is part of what motivates him to continue racing.

"[It's] obviously another driving factor to that, wanting to come out here," Busch said ahead of his qualifying run. "We only get a chance to do that once a year to try to win that race."

Though he's been in the sport for over two decades now, Busch says he has no plans to retire and still wants to win races.

The remainder of the Daytona 500 field will be set in Thursday's Daytona Duel races. The Daytona 500 is Sunday at 2:30 p.m.

title: Arizona Cardinals looking to trade Kyler Murray before 2026 new league year
description: The NFL offseason is upon us, and trades will likely begin to trickle in. With the NFL Combine a couple of weeks away, you can expect deals to be made behind closed doors in Indianapolis. One of the hottest namesâ€¦
fullText:
The NFL offseason is upon us, and trades will likely begin to trickle in. With the NFL Combine a couple of weeks away, you can expect deals to be made behind closed doors in Indianapolis.

One of the hottest names expected to be on the market is Arizona Cardinals quarterback Kyler Murray. The former first-overall pick appears to be on the outside looking in after being benched in 2025 and Arizona hiring a new head coach.

MORE: Las Vegas Raiders snatch up former Chargers, Titans head coach to staff

A lot can change between now and the new league year, but the Cardinals are reportedly beginning to explore trade options. There will be challenges with his contract this year, however.

"A change of scenery is best for all parties involved."@FieldYates weighs in on Kyler Murray's future with the Cardinals

â€” NFL on ESPN (@ESPNNFL) February 12, 2026

After 2026, Murrayâ€™s contract will have no more guarantees. However, a trading party takes on $34M this season in salaryâ€“unless Arizona takes on some of that salary.

Then there is also the idea of compensation. That $34M figure will likely influence trade compensation. If the Cardinals were to eat some of that money, it could reasonably be expected that they would get a better return in a trade.

MORE: George Kittle sends message to 49ers, NFL over wild conspiracy theory

The Cardinals want to get this done quickly, as Murrayâ€™s base salary becomes guaranteed four days after the 2026 new league year date. They could potentially post-June 1 release him, but that would leave no return.

Murray has been linked to multiple teams, including the Indianapolis Colts, New York Jets, and even the Cleveland Browns. The Colts are uncertain of Daniel Jonesâ€™ recovery timeline, the Jets will likely move on from Fields, and the Browns are always looking for a quarterback.

One thing feels almost certain: Murray will be in a different uniform only a few years after signing a hefty contract extension. How much interest there will be is yet to be seen.

title: U.S. routs Latvia in Olympic hockey opener
description: The U.S. men's hockey team scored four unanswered goals, and had a few taken away, led by a pair from Brock Nelson on Thursday in Milan.
fullText:
Brock Nelson might be making his Olympics debut, but he has a rich family history when it comes to playing hockey for Team USA.

His grandfather was a forward on the team that won gold in 1960. His uncle was a forward on the â€œMiracle on Iceâ€ team in 1980.

And Thursday night, Nelson made a mark of his own. The Colorado Avalanche forward scored two goals to lead the U.S. to a 5-1 victory over Latvia in an opening game that included some of the best American NHL players.

â€œItâ€™s pretty crazy,â€ said Nelson, 34, considered the old man on a team filled with some of the gameâ€™s brightest young stars. â€œItâ€™s just an unbelievable experience. Iâ€™m trying to soak it all in.â€

The Americans had to show resilience after two of their goals were wiped out in the first period by successful challenges. Itâ€™s rare to have two such reversals in a game, exceedingly rare to have two in the same period.

â€œYeah, that was frustrating,â€ said defenseman Zach Werenski, who plays for the Columbus Blue Jackets. â€œBut at the same time, youâ€™re still getting the goals even though they got overturned. Youâ€™re doing the work to put the puck in the net, and I think that helps your confidence a little bit. After they get overturned, youâ€™ve just got to put it out of your mind and continue to play the same way.â€

Latvia was competitive early, forging a 1-1 tie in the first period, but eventually fell prey to a U.S. barrage. The Americans outshot Latvia, 38-18, and starter Connor Hellebuyck needed to make only 17 saves.

â€œIt was just 1-1 but there was never any panic,â€ said forward Matthew Tkachuk, the Florida Panthers winger. â€œFrom the second period on, we just wanted to make sure someone was at the net at all times. They were playing pretty tight, but with the skill and puck possession and strength that we have, we knew we were going to win some battles.â€

Nelson, who said he takes a ribbing from his young teammates for his graying hair, has a rich family history when it comes to Olympic hockey. His grandfather, Bill Christian, won gold at the Games in Squaw Valley â€” now called Olympic Valley â€” and his uncle, Dave Christian, was on that championship team in Lake Placid.

â€œMy brother came in today,â€ said Nelson, raised in Minneapolis. â€œHe brought me a couple pins from back home, from 'Hockeytown,' and a couple letters from the youth team. Theyâ€™ve always been supportive of me, going back to growing up there. Iâ€™m forever grateful for that.â€

The U.S. team features brothers Matthew and Brady Tkachuk, and Quinn and Jack Hughes â€” all NHL players. It has been 12 years since NHL players last took the Olympic stage.

â€œTo make this roster is extremely difficult when you look at the amount of talent that the United States has developed and can play at this level,â€ said coach Mike Sullivan, who doubles as coach of the New York Rangers.

The fans were fairly evenly divided, with every U-S-A chant countered with one for LAT-VI-A.

â€œIt was great to see the flags, the chants, and just the support that you have here,â€ said U.S. forward Brady Tkachuk, who was raised in a suburb of St. Louis and plays for the Ottawa Senators. â€œI'm just kind of a little example of the support you have back at home. So you're playing in front of millions of millions of Americans, and you just want to represent them well, and itâ€™s always an honor to put this jersey on.â€

This story originally appeared in Los Angeles Times.

title: Dive behind the scenes of the breakthrough Williamsburg swim team
description: Williamsburg's swim team is writing inspiring history with its largest roster ever. Meet the individuals making it possible.
fullText:
Dec. 17, 2025, was a historic night for Williamsburg High School's athletic program.

During a swim meet at New Richmond High School, the Wildcats, whose team has grown from two athletes in 2024-2025 to 10 swimmers this year, fielded a boys relay team and girls relay team for the first time in school history.

"I never really got to be in a high school relay and having it my senior year was even more special for me. It's really going to be a core memory as long as I live," Taylor Sefton said.

For the majority of her career, Sefton has been one of the only swimmers on a Williamsburg team that is now rapidly growing under the supervision of her father, fourth-year coach Bill Sefton.

"They all work well together. They're a fantastic team. They all get along, nobody has any problems and they work hard. I can't ask for anything else as a coach," Bill said.

Taylor started the 2024-2025 season alongside Cameron Karschnik, whose older brother, Jonah, was a two-time state qualifier in the 100-yard butterfly. Cameron couldn't finish the season due to a back injury, but Bill is hopeful that he'll return next season.

In the twilight of her high school career, Taylor is attempting to become just the second female swimmer at Williamsburg to qualify for the state meet. Betsy Brockman won back-to-back 200-yard individual medley state titles in 2001 and 2002, setting a previous DII state record with a time of 2:04.98 as a senior.

"It would just be another accomplishment for myself. If I can only make districts four times in a row and I end up not making state, I won't be too upset because I know the work I put in wasn't for nothing," Taylor said.

Bill keeps a time board at practice, a chart of each swimmer's best times and which strokes they will compete in at upcoming meets. In the bottom right corner of the board is the list of school records he has found. Taylor's name is listed next to five of the seven individual records; Brockman owns the other two.

Junior Jarvis Zach, who owns the 50-yard freestyle school record, has one of the more interesting experiences on the team. Before this school year, he emigrated from Germany to live with his grandma and is waiting for his parents to get an approved visa so they can move to the United States. His mother was a swimming teacher and encouraged him to try the sport.

Moving to the United States, he immediately noticed differences in the practice and meet structure from his homeland, where sports are more club-oriented, as opposed to high school competition.

"I did swimming once in Germany, but it was for maybe two weeks and I really enjoyed it. Also in my free time, I swim a lot so I decided to join the swim team. I heard that it was starting new so I wanted to see how it was," Zach said.

In joining the swim team, Zach hopes to recruit others to continue to grow the program.

Carter Conatser joined halfway through this season after recovering from a football injury. He runs track in the spring and was looking for a way to keep his conditioning up.

"By the time track would come around, I'd die for the first three or four weeks doing conditioning," Conatser said. "I love this sport. It's the perfect sport to get into shape and feel loose by the time spring comes around."

As first-year swimmers on a team with seven freshmen, Zach and Conatser are quickly learning that, despite their inexperience, they need to be leaders for their younger counterparts.

"Being an upperclassman and at the same time learning a completely new sport is a very tough thing to do. Trying to encourage others to do their best while also trying to get up to where their level is has definitely been an adjustment," Conatser said.

On a team where everyone is teaching each other new skills, freshman Mallory Murphy stands out. She showed up on the first day of practice with all the confidence in the world but was quickly humbled when she discovered that she didn't know how to swim.

"I was flailing in the water. I would swim and I wasn't moving. I would basically be standing still in the water but I kept going because everybody was like, 'You're doing good. You're growing.' All my teammates were always there for me. They didn't let me get upset about not doing good. So I just kept trying and I never gave up," Murphy said.

Said Bill, "She comes to practice every day and completes all her sets. We couldn't be more proud of all the kids on the team."

Filling out the freshman class is Norah Bates, Owen Bickett, Landon Johnson, Sophia Lincoln, Jakob Karajic and Marley Minning. According to Sefton's research, Johnson already owns the 100-yard breaststroke school record.

"It's my first year swimming and I will say the community here is great - the whole swim community, not just our team," Lincoln said.

Then there's eighth-grader Bailey Sefton, who can't yet swim on varsity but Bill believes she will break Taylor's records, and even some of Brockman's over the next four years.

Bill anticipates adding three total swimmers next year.

"Hopefully next season, we start off with water acclimation and my group that's already been doing it, they in turn teach the other kids that are coming into the program," Bill said.

The Wildcats instantly set school records in the 200-yard medley relay and 200-yard freestyle relay, and Sefton hopes to have enough swimmers in 2026-2027 to field a 400-yard freestyle relay team, but this season has been about so much more than the times.

At the start of the season, the majority of the team was warming up with just swimming one lap of freestyle. Now, they start practice with a 500-yard warm-up before focusing on different strokes.

The amount of behind-the-scenes work hasn't gone unnoticed either. Assistant coach Logan Minning is a teacher at Williamsburg and the mother of freshman Marley Minning. Being at the school during the day allows her to communicate with athletic director Jason Moberly, the athletes and parents while Sefton works as a firefighter and Emergency Medical Technician.

"She's been a huge help for me. I'm so thankful to have her as part of the team," Bill said.

Williamsburg is building a new multi-purpose athletic center, but it doesn't have a pool, so the team practices at the Clermont Family YMCA in Batavia. The Ohio High School Athletic Association allows high school teams to practice for 90 minutes a day and the staff at the Y allows the Wildcats to use the pool whenever they need it.

"They've been great. They're awesome, letting us practice whenever we want. I give them the majority of the credit because we couldn't have made it happen without them," Bill said.

A few team members will even take jobs as lifeguards, helping to further advance their aquatic pedigree.

Williamsburg's team seemingly came out of nowhere this year, but it has been a work in progress from day one. This team isn't one large story, it's a collection of individual triumphs, adding to the school's distinguished athletic history.

This article originally appeared on Cincinnati Enquirer: Williamsburg High School swim team grows, inspires, breaks records

title: MSU hockey takes over No. 1 overall seed in latest bracketology
description: See who the Spartans are projected to play in the NCAA Tournament in the latest batch of bracketology from USCHO.com
fullText:
If the season ended today, Michigan State hockey would be the No. 1 overall seed in the NCAA Tournament. And also gets an interesting draw in the tournament, according to USCHO.com.

USCHO.com released their latest batch of college hockey bracketology, and it has the Spartans landing as the No. 1 seed in the Loveland Region. Michigan State is projected to play Bentley in the first round, who is the lowest ranked team currently slated to make the field. The other matchup in the Spartans' region is No. 2 seed Cornell vs. No. 3 seed Denver -- which would pit a team who knocked out the Spartans in last year's tournament against a team that would have a relative home ice advantage.

Michigan State recently took over as the No. 1 team in the NPI rankings -- which are used to seed and field the 16 teams that'll make the NCAA Tournament. In gaining the overall No. 1 seed, Michigan State would be in line for a notably easier matchup than if they were lower in the seeding lines.

Michigan State sits at 22-6-0 overall and 13-5-0 in Big Ten play with six regular season games remaining. The Spartans are off this weekend and will return to action next week against Notre Dame.

title: Jesse Minterâ€™s father Rick is part of his new staff in Baltimore
description: OWINGS MILLS, Md. (AP) â€” Jesse Minter's father Rick is part of his new staff in Baltimore.The Ravens announced their full coaching staff on Thursday. Jesse Minter was hired as the coach after John Harbaugh was fired. Minter hired Declan Doyle as offensive coordinator, Anthony Weaver as defensive coordinator and Anthony Levine as special teams coordinator.
fullText:
OWINGS MILLS, Md. (AP) â€” Jesse Minter's father Rick is part of his new staff in Baltimore.

The Ravens announced their full coaching staff on Thursday. Jesse Minter was hired as the coach after John Harbaugh was fired. Minter hired Declan Doyle as offensive coordinator, Anthony Weaver as defensive coordinator and Anthony Levine as special teams coordinator. Those additions were announced previously.

Volker as safeties coach; and Israel Woolfork as quarterbacks coach.

Rick Minter was previously a senior defensive analyst for the Los Angeles Chargers, when Jesse Minter was their defensive coordinator. The elder Minter was the University of Cincinnatiâ€™s head coach from 1994-2003.

title: Report: Dan Campbell Sends Message by Blocking Dolphinsâ€™ Interview Request
description: The Detroit Lions blocked the Dolphinsâ€™ request to interview Bruce Gradkowski â€” denying help to new Miami head coach and former Packers DC Jeff Hafley.
fullText:
The Detroit Lions arenâ€™t just protecting their coaching staff, theyâ€™re also leaning into a familiar rivalry.

According to NFL insider Jordan Schultz, the Miami Dolphins, now led by former Green Bay Packers defensive coordinator Jeff Hafley, requested permission to interview Lions offensive assistant Bruce Gradkowski for their quarterbacks coach position. Dan Campbell reportedly blocked the request, making it clear that Gradkowski isnâ€™t going anywhere.

Given Hafleyâ€™s Packers ties, the move feels especially fitting.

Dan Campbell and the Lions have spent years battling Green Bay for control of the NFC North, and now that a former Packers coordinator is running Miami, Detroit had little incentive to do any favors. Blocking the request not only keeps a valued coach in-house, it also denies help to a former rival.

Gradkowski has been with the Lions since 2025 and is viewed internally as a rising offensive mind. Before arriving in Detroit, he served as the offensive coordinator for the St. Louis BattleHawks of the UFL, helping build an offense that put him firmly on the NFL coaching radar.

As a player, Gradkowski starred at Toledo before being selected by the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in the sixth round of the 2006 NFL Draft. He went on to play for the St. Louis Rams, Cleveland Browns, Oakland Raiders, Cincinnati Bengals, and Pittsburgh Steelers, carving out a long professional career. His younger brother, Gino Gradkowski, is also a former NFL player.

Detroitâ€™s decision sends a clear message: Bruce Gradkowski is part of the Lionsâ€™ present â€” and future â€” and Dan Campbell isnâ€™t about to help a former Packers coach rebuild elsewhere.

title: Bears S review: Grading Kevin Byard, Jaquan Brisker in 2025
description: Our Bears position group review continues with safety, which had more continuity than we've seen in a long time.
fullText:
The Chicago Bears had a magical 2025 season under first-year head coach Ben Johnson, where they went from worst to first with an 11-6 record, NFC North title and the franchise's first playoff win in 15 years. And there's no denying that the future is bright.

While the Bears exceeded expectations in their first year under Johnson, there's still plenty of work to be done with this roster, most notably on defense. After overhauling the offense in the trenches and at skill positions, the focus shifts to the defense where the hope is general manager Ryan Poles does the same to round out this unit under defensive coordinator Dennis Allen and form a complete team with a top-five offense.

Here at Bears Wire, we're going position by position through the 2025 Bears and grading every player. Rounding out the defense are the safeties, which had more continuity than we have seen in a long time. All four safeties played in 17 games this season and featured an All-Pro, Kevin Byard.

2025 stats: 93 total tackles, 4 for loss, 7 interceptions, 8 pass breakups (17 games)

Kevin Byard turned back the clock in 2025 with one of his best seasons in his 10-year career. The ball-hawking safety was all over the place in 2025, leading the league in interceptions while baiting quarterbacks into making poor throws. In Week 4 alone, Byard caught Las Vegas Raiders quarterback Geno Smith sleeping by picking him off twice on the same play. The team captain used his savvy veteran skills many times to break up deeper passes and keep a leaky secondary from breaking down. For his efforts, Byard was named First-Team All-Pro and made the Pro Bowl, both for the third time in his career. The only downside to Byard's season is he allowed more touchdowns (seven) than ever before, but all in all, 2025 was one to remember. It should be enough to warrant a contract extension as Byard enters free agency.

2025 stats: 93 total tackles, 1 for loss, 1 sack, 3 QB hits, 1 interception, 8 pass breakups (17 games)

One of the biggest questions heading into the 2025 season was how Jaquan Brisker would look and hold up as he made his return to the field. Brisker hadn't seen any action since October of 2024 due to suffering a scary concussion that sidelined him for the rest of the season. But to his credit, Brisker came back strong and played all 17 games for the first time in his career. The fourth-year safety wasn't as impactful as Byard and struggled in pass coverage, allowing a 127.6 passer rating. Some of Brisker's struggles were due to injuries around him, though. Because the Bears rarely had their complete cornerback group on the field together, Brisker wasn't able to play the Swiss Army Knife role he does so well. When the Bears eventually got healthy in the secondary, Brisker shined. That was evident in the divisional playoff game against the Los Angeles Rams when Brisker notched 14 tackles, one for a loss, a sack, and two pass breakups. Like Byard, Brisker is also an impending free agent, though his return isn't nearly as certain. If he played his last game as a Bear, Brisker made sure it counted.

2025 stats: 19 total tackles (17 games)

In prior seasons, Elijah Hicks was pressed into starting duty due to injuries for a stretch of games. That wasn't the case in 2025, though, so the fourth-year safety had fewer opportunities to make an impact on defense. He had some shine, though. Hicks saw extended time playing against the Pittsburgh Steelers and Cleveland Browns and made key plays in both games. He primarily contributed on special teams, however, proving to be a quality option for Richard Hightower's group. Hicks is a solid depth player who could find his way back to the Bears in 2026 as he enters free agency.

2025 stats: 19 total tackles (17 games)

In his second season with the Bears, Jonathan Owens was primarily a special teams player and didn't see too much time at safety. Like Hicks, he saw limited snaps on defense with Byard and Brisker staying healthy. As the season went on, Hicks overtook Owens as the third safety in specific coverage packages. Owens flew under the radar for much of the year on the field, though his wife, Simone Biles, made sure he was newsworthy otherwise. He's another pending free agent, and his future with the Bears is up in the air.

The best ability is availability, and the Bears safeties aced that test, having played in every single game, including the postseason. That's an accomplishment on its own. Kevin Byard was very clearly the star of the position group, having led the team in interceptions and anchoring the back seven of the defense. While Jaquan Brisker's play wasn't as consistent as originally hoped, he made key plays throughout the year and bounced back from a serious injury. All in all, it was a solid season for this group, but with every player hitting free agency, it's going to look much different in 2026.

This article originally appeared on Bears Wire: Bears S review: Grading Kevin Byard, Jaquan Brisker in 2025

title: Trinidad Chambliss wins another year of college eligibility
description: Ole Miss quarterback Trinidad Chambliss has secured the ability to return to the program for another year.
fullText:
Ole Miss quarterback Trinidad Chambliss has secured the ability to return to the program for another year.

Via Pete Thamel of ESPN.com, a Mississippi judge has granted Chambliss a preliminary injunction against the NCAA. Among other things, the judge concluded that the NCAA acted in bad faith when denying Chambliss a medical redshirt based on a respiratory issue that kept him from playing in 2022, while enrolled at Ferris State. He didn't play a single snap that year, and he didn't dress for games.

The selection of a Mississippi state court clearly helped Chambliss. It's a home-court advantage to have the case resolved by a Mississippi judge who was elected by (and presumably hopes to be re-elected by) Mississippi voters. As it would be for any student at any school based in any state where the NCAA operates.

Given that the order will apply as the case proceeds, Chambliss will be permitted to play unless the presiding judge resolves the case in the NCAA's favor before the end of the 2026 season â€” or unless the NCAA can overturn the ruling via appeal to a higher Mississippi court.

In the face of its latest courtroom failure, the NCAA was predictably defiant.

"This decision in a state court illustrates the impossible situation created by differing court decisions that serve to undermine rules agreed to by the same NCAA members who later challenge them in court," the NCAA said in a statement. "We will continue to defend the NCAA's eligibility rules against repeated attempts to rob future generations of the opportunity to compete in college and experience the life-changing opportunities only college sports can create.

"The NCAA and its member schools are making changes to deliver more benefits to student-athletes, but the patchwork of state laws and inconsistent, conflicting court decisions make partnering with Congress essential to provide stability for current and future college athletes."

That's code for the ongoing plea to get Congress to federalize college sports, and to allow the schools to return to the days of blatant antitrust violations. To date, that effort has gone nowhere.

And the NCAA's ridiculous sky-is-falling! message is exhausting. If Trinidad Chambliss, or anyone else, has remaining eligibility, he should be entitled to use it. If the folks at Ole Miss decide it's in the best interests of the program to keep Chambliss on the field and if he can show that the rules should give him another year, the ridiculous rhetoric about "future generations" being "robbed" of "opportunity" should be ignored. It's not making the NCAA's current situation or reputation any better.

In recent years, the NCAA has gradually been exposed as nothing more than a shield behind which the various schools had previously hidden to justify not paying players. And even though the NCAA surely pines for the days when it had real power, the institution is currently nothing more than a toothless, arbitrary bureaucracy.

Frankly, the sooner the NCAA goes away, the better off the member universities and their student-athlete-employees will be. The NCAA is currently trying to help only itself, by finding a solution to the current college-sports chaos that doesn't result in the NCAA's extinction.

title: Trinidad Chambliss wins case amid NCAA lawyers ghosting the judge
description: The Ole Miss QB picks up his biggest victory.
fullText:
Trinidad Chambliss wins case amid NCAA lawyers ghosting the judge originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The NCAAâ€™s absence spoke almost as loudly as the judgeâ€™s ruling.

On Thursday afternoon in a Mississippi courtroom, Trinidad Chambliss was granted a preliminary injunction that effectively awards him an extra year of eligibility, clearing the way for the Ole Miss quarterback to play in 2026.

But as Judge Robert Whitwell prepared to deliver his decision, one detail stood out. The NCAAâ€™s counsel had already left the courtroom and was not present for the final ruling. The hearing in Pittsboro, Miss. marked the culmination of a fight between Chambliss, Ole Miss officials and the NCAA over whether a medically sidelined 2022 season at Ferris State Bulldogs should count against his eligibility clock.

In 20+ years of law practice, I've never seen opposing counsel leave the court before the decision was rendered. That's bizarre. https://t.co/Z1Q8LQS0xF

â€” We Run the Sip (@OMRebelNation) February 12, 2026

Chambliss did not dress for a game that year, battling significant respiratory issues before undergoing a tonsillectomy. The NCAA denied his waiver request three separate times, including an initial application, an appeal and a reconsideration request submitted with additional medical documentation.

The association maintained that he was not denied the opportunity to compete and therefore did not qualify for a medical hardship waiver.

Ole Miss officials sharply disagreed, arguing that the documented medical circumstances warranted approval at the staff level. After exhausting internal NCAA channels, Chambliss filed suit in Chancery Court, seeking both preliminary and permanent injunctive relief.

More:Â Demond Williams bombshell could've resulted in Lane Kiffin being fired at LSU

The financial stakes are substantial. Chamblissâ€™ return to Oxford is tied to a compensation package reportedly exceeding $5 million in name, image and likeness earnings. It's a figure that shows the shifting economic realities of college football.

The judgeâ€™s ruling allows Chambliss to take the field while the broader legal battle continues. However, the NCAAâ€™s early exit added an unusual twist to a case that could carry significant implications for future eligibility disputes nationwide.

Oregon's Dan Lanning rips College Football Playoff, calls for major changes

title: 2026 Season Preview: FC Anyang
description: Bruno Mota may have departed, but behind the scenes, Anyang are confident they can improve on last season's eighth-place finish. Minimal recruitment, combined with an aging squad of out-of-contract st...
fullText:
Bruno Mota may have departed, but behind the scenes, Anyang are confident they can improve on last season's eighth-place finish. Minimal recruitment, combined with an aging squad of out-of-contract stars, suggests this could be a more challenging season for the Violets.

A debut K League 1 season of a few lows, but numerous highs. It was a memorable year covering Anyang for the website â€” I can't imagine how special it was as a fan or a player. After several near misses, Anyang won promotion in 2024 and knew they faced a tough season. Their squad was the oldest in the league and lacked real experience at this level. But it didn't matter. Anyang finished eighth, well clear of relegation, with the foundations built to become a K League 1 regular.

The low point of the season was a dreadful summer run that saw the team lose six in seven matches and drop to 11th. That run looked set to continue when Daejeon led 2-1 with time running out in August. However, a red card and a Matheus Oliveira double rescued the game â€” and their season. That kick-started a seven-game unbeaten run, which included a historic win in Seoul.

Han Ka-ram celebrates his Goal of the Month against Gimcheon.

Survival was effectively guaranteed when Anyang played kingmaker before the split. In their best performance of the year, Gimcheon Sangmu were slaughtered, thanks in part to Han Ka-ram's wonder goal. The 4-1 win handed Jeonbuk Hyundai the title, cementing Anyang's right to be taken seriously. This club has arrived.

Brazilian striker Bruno Mota has joined K League 1 champions Jeonbuk Hyundai Motors on loan until the end of the season, but Anyang don't expect him to return. The big striker enjoyed a glorious single season in Anyang, leading the line in their debut K League 1 campaign. His 14 goals will be difficult to replace, not to mention his positive contribution to the clubhouse atmosphere.

FC Anyang is an old team, especially in defence and goal. Kim Da-sol was a brilliant signing, leading the team to promotion and then eighth place in K League 1. Da-sol is out of contract next winter and, at 37, is nearing the end of his career. Jeong-hoon (24) started the Cup final win over Gwangju and can now bide his time before taking over between the sticks.

The man entrusted with the impossible task of replacing Bruno Mota is 26-year-old forwardÂ Breno Herculano, on loan from CRB in Brazil's Serie B. Anyang love the lone target man who is quick, holds the ball up, chases lost causes down the flanks, and is good in the air. Herculano will also need to score goals. In his professional career, he has averaged exactly one goal every five matches.

Thomas Oude Kotte scored one of the most important goals in Anyang's history.

A player who needs no introduction. Thomas is already a legend in Anyang after a stunning debut season that saw him nominated for the Best XI and earn a call-up for Team K League against Newcastle United. Thomas began life in Korea as a centre-back, then shifted to left-back, before operating at a very high level in midfield. This form and versatility saw his name linked with several big clubs, but Anyang moved quickly to offer him a new deal. He was recently named vice-captain.

Winger Chae features in this category for the second straight season, and it is no surprise. The 21-year-old was nominated for K League 1 Young Player of the Season thanks to four goals in 33 appearances. Chae was involved in more matchday squads than any other Anyang player. With Yago's move to Malaysia, Chae is likely to be busy again in 2026.

Officials at Anyang are confident the club can improve on their 2025 final position, but until they secure an obvious replacement for Bruno Mota, that is hard to envisage. Mota was a brilliant signing â€” the right man at the right time. Anyang went up in 2024 without a recognised goalscorer. They fixed that by signing the K League 2 top goalscorer, Mota.

The Brazilian was an instant hit. He headed home the winner on his debut in Ulsan, one of 14 league goals. He earned a nomination for the Best XI and played 90 minutes for Team K League in the glamour friendly with Newcastle United. Off the field, the impact was just as strong. Anyang players told me throughout the year that Mota was the natural link between the Brazilians and the Koreans â€” the man who acted as the go-between. Those are big boots to fill.

Anyang have shown themselves to be a model that all city-owned, small-market clubs can aspire to. Building a squad comes down to budgets, smart scouting, and effective player retention, but where Anyang really excel is off the pitch. They have the same disadvantages as many of their competitors: a slightly dilapidated, large multipurpose stadium that isn't fit for football. There's no shelter from rain, snow, or sun, and thousands of seats offer a poor view.

So what was the response? Build three pitchside temporary stands to minimise the impact of the running track. It isn't pretty, but it is very effective. They also added a new club beer â€” Sukhavati â€” and made â€œZombieâ€ the new club anthem. As a result, Anyang have generated one of the best matchday experiences in Korea. You don't need the Pohang Steel Yard to make it fun.
